codefordc.description:
6:30 - 7:00 Participants arrive and socialize. 

7:00 - 7:15 Group introductions and announcements from participants and organizers.

7:15 - 9:15 Hacking. Project teams break out to work.  New participants can join teams, circulate, or seek out the Co-Captains for orientation (Justin, Matt, or Leah).

~7:30 Food delivered. 

9:15 - 9:30 Everyone reconvenes and shares reactions to and progress made over the last two hours. Show and tell if time/resources allow it. Thank you and goodnight.

9:30 Sometimes an after party (Happy Hour)

Notes: 

• Text Matt 202-330-1154 or Justin at 301-538-5812 for entry if no one is at the door.

• Bring cash for food and drink! Pay what you can.

If you are new to Code for DC… 

• Bring a laptop if you can (it’s ok if you can’t) 

• Take a look at our active projects

• Review the Code for DC Code of Conduct

• Check out our Getting Started Guide https://github.com/codefordc/getting-started

• Start working on a project with someone or bring your own project


• Introduce yourself to others

• If you had a good time join Google Group and Meetup
codefordc.name: Civic Hacknight

other.description:
Meetup Format 

The Front End Hack Night (FEHN) study group is a space where women can come together and help each other learn and understand web development. We welcome devs of all levels and encourage those with more experience to help out those that are just starting. 

There's always at least one mentor/leader present to help you with best practices or to guide you through if you are stuck with a nasty problem! Every study group will have the following format:

• 6:30pm - Begin

• 6:40 - 6:50pm - Quick Introductions

• 6:50 - 8:00pm - CODE!

• 8:00 - 8:15pm - Lightning Talk (a quick presentation or talk) (if scheduled)

• 8:15 - 8:30pm - Wrap Up

RESOURCES

To learn more about us please visit, http://bit.ly/frontendhacknight

Building Access

Certain building managements requires meetup hosts to let people in and do not encourage them being contacted. Please respect the policy, in case the location requires access to the building contact the group lead if information is provided, or drop a comment on the meetup page. We'll come and get you.

All Women Welcome 

This event is intended to be exclusively open for people who identify as women - we are transgender friendly.
other.name: Front End Hack Night

other.description:
Interested in learning how to build Android apps with an awesome group of women?  Looking to build your first app or build on existing skills?  Come to our weekly Android hack night!  We welcome women with all levels of Android experience (including none), but coding experience is preferred as Android is not the friendliest way to learn how to code. 

Meetup Format

We will set up stations according to level of experience and provide you with recommended resources to work through as a group.  You will be able to ask your fellow coders questions and help each other work through issues.  We encourage any advanced Android developers and enthusiasts to come and help others!  There will also be at least one mentor present to help you with best practices or guide you if you are stuck with a problem!  

Building Access

The management in certain buildings requires meetup hosts to let people in instead of relying on their security staff.   Please respect the policy in case the location requires access to the building.  To gain access, contact the group lead if information is provided or drop a comment on the meetup page. We'll come get you. 

Resources
This is our Android Start Here document.  It's chock full of information to get you up and running.  It is a work in progress and we'll be adding as we go. Suggestions welcomed!  

All Women Welcome


This event is intended to be exclusively open for women and those who identify as women; we are transgender friendly.
other.name: Android Hack Night

other.description:
Interested in learning Ruby and Rails with an awesome group of women? Looking to build your first web app, learn more about coding, or build on existing skills? Come to our weekly ROR study group! We welcome women with all levels of experience. Check out this guide to better understand what we do:bit.ly/rorstudygroupguide. We encourage any advanced ROR devs to come and help others! 

There's always at least one mentor present to help you with best practices or guide you through if you are stuck with a nasty problem! 

Contact policy at buildings that need access 

Certain building managements requires meetup hosts to let people in and do not encourage them being contacted. Please respect the policy, in case the location requires access to the building contact the group lead if information is provided, or drop a comment on the meetup page. We'll come and get you. 

Want to be a Ruby on Rails Study Group leader? 

If you are passionate about learning ROR with fellow awesome women and want to help us, come on out!  Drop us a message or email us and let us know that you are interested in helping us with the Rails study group!

RESOURCES

These are the resources that members have been following along, feel free to suggest if you have more to add!

http://bit.ly/wwcrailsguide 

This event is intended to be exclusively open for people who identify as women - we are transgender friendly.
other.name: Ruby on Rails Study Group

other.description:
All sorts of good data is trapped in HTML (... the Internet) or XML (as a theoretically human-readable format). Getting it out can be rough.

This March, we'll work through a couple files with some tricky problems (mistakes in the tags! Encoding!) using Python and learn about how to think about this data.

Bring your laptop or plan to look on with someone else. We'll be working through some problems, but much of the magic is in understanding your data and the tree structure of XML.

Please try to install Beautiful Soup (pip install beautiful_soup4 or http://www.crummy.com/software/BeautifulSoup/).

As usual, we meet at 6:30 and start in on some pizza... we'll get started around 7. If you have a file of XML or HTML for us to play with, comment below!
other.name: Parsing HTML and XML data with Python

other.description:
Winter won in February.  it came, it saw, it messed with our meetup.  

Not this time.  


The March DC API meetup will be one of the greatest API meetups of your life.*  Spring time is upon us. Winter be damned. APIs in 2015 will do more and reach further than we've seen yet.  We've got a great lineup of presenters, not to mention lots of pizza and beer, so come be the judge for yourself!  

6:00pm - 6:45pm Food, drinks and networking 
6:45pm - 6:55pm Introductions and Announcements 
6:55pm - 8:00pm Presentations

* Leah Bannon, 18F
* Larry Williams
* Dave Shewfelt, Captricity

7:55pm - 8:00pm Refill your beverage 
8:00pm - 8:30pm Panel discussions 
8:30pm - 9:00pm Networking

* Okay, that ... may be an exaggeration but there's a lot of great folks who are looking to make it pan out, so come and see if I'm right.
other.name: DC API User Group - March Edition

other.name: Monthly Meetup

other.description:
IMPORTANT: - Registration is through Eventbrite. 


OVERVIEW

Join the Web Content Mavens and learn about managing marketing and communications across multiple channels - including web, email, social and mobile. 


Key takeaways:
• Overview of different channels
• When to use each and how they tie together
• Planning a cross-platform communications/marketing campaign
• Tone, language & terminology
• Carrying a brand across properties
• Visual identity cues
• Customer/member participation & advocacy

SPEAKERS

Brenna Holmes, VP of Digital, Chapman, Cubine, Adams + Hussey

Brenna leads the Interactive Department’s digital/ mobile teams, delivering multichannel integration and SMART digital acquisition. She possesses an extensive background in cross-channel marketing and advocacy integration and loves starting digital or mobile programs from scratch or taking one to the next level. Her specialty is creating unified surround sound campaigns that maximize supporter engagement and organizational loyalty by integrating traditional direct marketing with innovative digital media. [masked]

Heather Shelby, Online Activist Coordinator, Environmental Defense Fund


Heather began her career by working as an email consultant  for members of Congress. Over six years ago, she decided to transition into the non-profit world by joining EDF’s membership team. As Environmental Defense Fund’s Online Activism Coordinator, she focuses on finding effective ways—whether online, through mobile, or in-person—to educate EDF members while connecting them with their elected officials in meaningful ways that actually have an impact.


Shashi Bellamkonda, VP of Digital Marketing, The Bozzuto Group


Shashi Bellamkonda is the Vice President, Digital Marketing at The Bozzuto Group and an adjunct faculty member of Georgetown University. After several years of enriching experience in the hospitality industry, including being a chef, Shashi transformed his hobby of computers and technology to his current career. Shashi was previously Senior Director, Social Media and Digital Marketing at Network Solutions. He has co-authored chapters in two books also been featured in 15 Books on marketing and social media. 

AGENDA


6:30 pm - Networking, drinks and appetizers
7:00 pm - Presentations
8:15 pm - More networking
8:45 pm - Adjourn

OUR SPONSOR

What’s next? Chapman Cubine Adams + Hussey (CCAH) has been seeking an answer to this question for more than 25 years. We’re driven to discover what’s next in multi-channel marketing and how we can help our clients test new ideas, embrace innovation and break through the clutter. www.ccah.com
other.name: Integrated Marketing & Communications - Online, Social & Mobile

other.description:
(Please note that you need to get a ticket through Eventbrite to attend: http://bamgdc.eventbrite.com/?aff=DCDevMeetup)

The Code Kitchen and Big Android Meat & Greet in the Washington, DC metro area on Saturday, April 4, 2015.


During the day, developers of any skill level can devour code challenges in our Code Kitchen, testing their Android know-how by solving one, two, or all of the challenges on our Code Kitchen Menu.

Want to extend the fun? Purchase a ticket for our evening event the Big Android Meat and Greet - join us as we dig into some world-famous Big Android BBQ and sail into the sunset on the historic Cherry Blossom riverboat with our crew, sponsors, and other Android enthusiasts just like you!

Tickets are available here: http://bamgdc.eventbrite.com/?aff=DCDevMeetup


More info: http://bamg.ideaa.io/dc/
other.name: Code Kitchen and Big Android Meat & Greet

venue.name: United States Patent and Trademark Office

other.description:
Saturday? Yup, we are changing things up and swapping out empenadas for bagels and other brunchy foods. Not only that, but we are joining forces with Data Innovation DC and District Data Labs to bring you this event! (You can register either here or at DIDC, but for the sake of headcount, please don't sign up in both places.)

Eight teams of DC data scientists have come together for a three month incubator to turn theory into practice on projects spanning healthcare, economics, the environment, and more. Learn from their experience implementing a Deep Learning network on commercially available hardware, on deploying a D3.js visualization web app using Heroku, or on building a desktop GUI with Python... plus much more! Enjoy brunch and drinks on us as we are taken from concept to production on eight data products, and then join the judges by voting for the winner! 

Please note that the event will be at GW but we have not finalized the exact space yet (so the address may change).


Agenda:

11:00 am -- Brunch and mingling

11:30 am -- Presentations!

1:00pm -- Go out for post-event mimosas (location TBA)

About our teams:

SeeFish: Kathleen, Matt, and Chris are entering the Kaggle National Data Science Bowl, for which they must analyze underwater images to quantify plankton populations using Deep Learning systems.

Group D: Constance, Vinoth, and Mike are developing an algorithm to accurately categorize overall ratings by the main contributing factor (e.g. service, food quality) as identified by the text in the corresponding review using a Yelp dataset.

In collaboration with the Department of Labor:

LaborMatch: Yunan, Keegan and Ali are combining BLS data with data via social media APIs to visualize skills-based supply/demand by geographic region and predict future trends in skill development using time-series and regression analysis.

OKJK: Jim, Kathleen, and Oliver are working to form a suite of compressed economic indicators by geographic region using BLS data to improve understanding of economic health.

PPM-Data: Patrick, Mehdi, and Paul are working to predict job growth using BLS economic data and regression analysis.

Group B: Danielle, Elaine, Jing and Will are visualizing pockets of excess demand by industry, skill and resource using BLS data.

In collaboration with HIMMS:

The Synthesizers: Jamie, Kenneth and Bohan are working with HIMMS to add functionality to an open source data synthesizer to generate synthetic patient data sets with variable corruption by field.

In collaboration with ZeroCycle:

The Planeteers: Tony, Eyuel and Kate are optimizing attribution of recycling behavior to hyper local geographical regions using ZeroCycle and Census data.

Sponsors:

This event is sponsored by the GWU Department of Decision Sciences, Pearson/InformIT, Statistics.com, Elder Research, and Novetta Solutions. (Would your organization like to sponsor too? Please get in touch!)
other.name: Data Brunch and Project Pitchfest!

Building Access

other.description:
Please join us April 9th for two talks on the Apache Mesos project and how it can be used with Spark.

Agenda

6:30 PM -- Networking & Food 

6:55 PM -- Greetings & Prizes

7:00 PM -- Flexibility and Speed with YARN, Spark, and other Big Data frameworks on Apache Mesos and the Mesosphere Datacenter Operating System - Ben Hindman

8:00 PM -- Fully Fault tolerant Streaming Workflows at Scale using Apache Mesos & Spark Streaming - Akhil Das

9:00 PM -- Post event drinks at Of Love & Regret

Location

Join us at the new home of Ad.com!

3700 O'Donnell Street

Baltimore, MD  21224

Parking

TBA

Talks

Flexibility and Speed with YARN, Spark, and other Big Data frameworks on Apache Mesos and the Mesosphere Datacenter Operating System

In this talk Ben Hindman, Co-creator of Mesos and Chief Architect at Mesosphere, will demonstrate a highly-elastic model for running YARN, Spark, and other Big Data frameworks on a single shared cluster, managed by Apache Mesos and the Mesosphere Datacenter Operating System (DCOS).  Ben will explain the history of Mesos and its common data science origins at the UC Berkeley AMPlab. He will also explain in detail how YARN and Spark run on Mesos and the Mesosphere DCOS, sharing resources amongst each other as well as with other workloads on the same cluster. He will also explain the uniqueness of the Mesos two-level scheduler, how it differs from YARN’s monolithic scheduler and how a modern datacenter can deploy diverse workloads (big data, batch, and long-running services) on a single Mesos or Mesosphere DCOS cluster, collaboratively sharing cluster resources.

Fully Fault tolerant Streaming Workflows at Scale using Apache Mesos & Spark Streaming

Spark streaming is one of the most powerful platforms on which to do computation or analytics over real time streaming data. Since the data is streaming in real time, you need a fault tolerant environment to get accurate results without losing any data. This talk will give you insight into how Mesos helps you to create a high availability cluster that can scale and run almost completely fault-tolerant spark streaming applications.


Speakers

Benjamin Hindman is a Founder and Chief Architect at Mesosphere, where he leads the core engineering team for the Mesosphere Data Center Operating System (DCOS). Ben co-created Apache Mesos as a PhD student at UC Berkeley before bringing it to Twitter where it now runs on tens of thousands of machines powering Twitter's datacenters. An academic at heart, his research in programming languages and distributed systems has been published in leading academic conferences. Ben can be followed on Twitter @benh


Akhil Das is a Software Developer at Sigmoid Analytics focusing on distributed computing, big data analytics, scaling and optimising performance.

Companies

Mesosphere (Twitter: @Mesosphere) is dedicated to helping enterprises unlock the next generation of datacenter scale, efficiency and automation with Apache Mesos. Mesosphere’s commercial product is the Mesosphere Datacenter Operating System (DCOS), a new kind of operating system that spans the entire datacenter and pools datacenter resources and automates IT operations. Backed by Andreessen Horowitz, Data Collective, Fuel Capital and Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers, Mesosphere is headquartered in San Francisco with a second office in Hamburg, Germany.


Sigmoid Analytics: Sigmoid's Sigmastream Platform on top of Apache Spark provides a framework for real time streaming & ETL on Spark. Sigmastream provides 500+ streaming operators & a SQL like language to easily build complex streaming pipelines. It can process millions event/sec & can scale to 100's node. It can be used for solving use cases like sensor data analytics, log analytics, fraud detection, etc.

Post Event Drinks

Of Love & Regret

1028 South Conkling Street, Baltimore
other.name: All about the Mesos: YARN, Spark, and Streaming

other.description:
Hack and Tell will be at WeWork Chinatown again in April! (Hooray!) Everyone is looking forward to hearing about *your* cool hack! Presentation signups are here:

http://bit.ly/presentatdc

The format is informal, engaging, and friendly: presenters have 5 minutes to show off their hack (it goes faster than you’d expect) and then the audience has 5 minutes to ask questions, make jokes, and suggest ideas and feedback. The hacks that people present are anything from how to train your dog to text you when it needs a walk to [something more serious... like blenders made out of artichokes]. Show us what you’ve got! But remember: no startup pitches, no dull work projects, no deckware!

If you’re interested in presenting, complete this short form to let us know: http://bit.ly/presentatdc

See you at the meetup! We'll start close to seven. There may be a couple beers. It's going to be fun! :) Big thanks to WeWork for hosting us! We love WeWork! We love you! We love hacks! <3
other.name: Round 19: Semi-Automatic Semaphore

Please respect the policy, in case the location requires access to the building contact the group lead if information is provided, or drop a comment on the meetup page. We'll come and get you. 

Want to be a Ruby on Rails Study Group leader? 

If you are passionate about learning ROR with fellow awesome women and want to help us, come on out!  Drop us a message or email us and let us know that you are interested in helping us with the Rails study group!

http://bit.ly/wwcrailsguide

other.name: Ruby on Rails Hack Night

other.description:
NOTE: Registration is through Eventbrite.

Join the Web Mavens for food, drink and discussions about using online tools & techniques to extend your message, create community, impact behavior and motivate action.

Learn about extending the reach of your message using web, social and mobile; using the "always-on" nature of social and mobile context to engage users in advocacy, giving, sharing and acting; impacting behavior both on & offline; crafting successful calls-to action; and integrating your online communication and engagement efforts into a coordinated campaign.  

Audience

This event is intended for people who want to motivate action- including engagement, advocacy and marketing - as well as the web and technology people involved in implementing solutions and developing the interaction. 

You do not need to be a techie to attend!

Why Attend?

Your calls to action and customer materials are being read on mobile, shared on social and experienced on websites - do you have a plan for how those pieces work together?

60% of website visits are from a mobile device - do you know if your communication and engagement tools are ready?

Different channels require different calls-to-action - do you know how to leverage that difference to motivate and engage?

Logistics  
6:30 - Check-in and networking 
7:00 - Presentation and Q&A 
8:45 - Wrap-up and more schmoozing 
9:15 - Close
other.name: Engage! Influence, Advocate & Motivate Online

other.description:
Solve our national PACER problem in 2015.


PACER, aka Public Access to Court Electronic Records, is the online system for accessing U.S. Federal District and Bankruptcy Courts. PACER requires a valid credit card and US taxpayer ID (amongst other things) to use. PACER charges ~10 cents a page with a maximum of $3 per document. If a user incurs less than $15 in charges per quarter, the fee for that quarter is waived. Additional charges are levied for docket reports in HTML, audio files, and searches of the PACER Case Locator.

Learn about how these charges are technologically excessive, how charging for access to the law is constitutionally questionable, and what you can do today to help free PACER, with a very special line-up of speakers, including: 

• Carl Malamud, author of "In re: The PACER System Memorandum of Law: A National Strategy of Litigation, Supplication, and Agitation", a three-part campaign to the free the law, amongst other things.

• Steve Schultze, co-creator of RECAP The Law (a free extension for Firefox and Chrome that improves the experience of using PACER, helping you archive law for the public good, save money, and keeping you organized), amongst other things.

• Harlan Yu, co-creator of </a><a href="https://www.recapthelaw.org/">RECAP The Law, amongst other things.


• Timothy B. Lee, co-creator of </a><a href="https://www.recapthelaw.org/">RECAP The Law, amongst other things. 


More speakers and details are coming. RSVP now, this will be a very special gathering. 

#FreePACER #LegalHack
other.name: #LegalHack PACER

other.description:
Recently, there has been significant buzz about the potential for new technologies to disrupt the market for legal services. In the meantime, a quiet "evolution" is occurring, as new digital tools are being integrated into traditional practice settings at a rapid pace. Inside forward-looking law firms and corporate legal departments, lawyers are creating technology-based solutions to increase the effectiveness of legal services. These lawyers are maintaining the highest quality of services while using technologies as a multiplier to drive down client costs. 

This important day-and-a-half conference, sponsored with the ABA Journal, examines how legal technologies are being adopted in many practice areas including litigation, transactional work, compliance, and intellectual property. Each panel's presenters will demonstrate how a new technology they have developed supports improved service delivery. Attendees will have the opportunity to learn how law firms and legal departments are using technology-based tools to address client needs and explore how these approaches enhance the effectiveness of law practice. 

The conference opens with the Iron Tech Lawyer competition on April 22nd from 1:15-3:30 and continues through April 23rd, with panels on technologies in litigation, digital tools in contract management, due diligence, and intellectual property, cross-practice technologies, legal technology careers, and access to justice and open government. 

REGISTRATION = $45 for members of DC Legal Hackers. 

YOU MUST REGISTER HERE.
other.name: From Revolution to Evolution - Digital Tools in Law Practice

other.description:
Oft requested but often avoided due to the pain that is install parties... a Django class! Learn the basics of using Django to create a basic app. We will be going over:

• Setting up a basic project


• Creating a model


• Setting up the admin


• Creating views


• Adding in templates


This class will be held remotely using the Cloud 9 IDE. This IDE is free, and will make troubleshooting your environment a ton easier for us! 

This class will be held via Google Hangouts on Air. You can watch it via YouTube or through Google+. There will also be a chat room where you can chat with other students and get help from volunteers. 

You will need:

• Coffee. We start early!


• A good Internet connection. Don't try to do this at a coffee shop!


• A Cloud 9 account (http://c9.io)

• A Github account (http://github.com)
other.name: Django in your PJ's (using Cloud 9)

other.description:
This event will be a fun collaboration with the Humanitarian OpenStreetMap Team. The Humanitarian OpenStreetMap Team [HOT] applies the principles of open source and open data sharing for humanitarian response and economic development.

1. Learn about the Humanitarian OpenStreetMapTeam (HOT)
2. Get introduced to OpenStreetMap and
3. Dive into contributing to a HOT project using the tasking manager.

OSM Tasking Manager is a mapping tool designed and built for the Humanitarian OSM Team collaborative mapping. The purpose of the tool is to divide up a mapping job into smaller tasks that can be completed rapidly. It shows which areas need to be mapped and which areas need the mapping validated. 


This approach facilitates the distribution of tasks to the various mappers in a context of emergency. It also permits to control the progress and the homogeinity of the work done (ie. Elements to cover, specific tags to use, etc.).
other.name: Introduction to OpenStreetMap for Humanitarian Response

other.description:
What You'll Learn

PL/R is a PostgreSQL extension that allows the use of R from within PostgreSQL for advanced analytics in a simple, efficient, and controlled manner. It has been available and actively maintained since January 2003. PL/R works with all supported versions of PostgreSQL, and all recent versions of R. It is used by thousands of people worldwide.

Recent trends in big data favor bringing the analytics closer to the data – meanwhile PL/R has been quietly providing this service for over 10 years! This presentation will introduce the audience to PL/R, discuss the pros and cons of this approach to data analysis, take you through basic usage, and finally illustrate its power with a few advanced examples.


Our Speaker

Joe Conway is an innovative leader with broad experience in a wide array of disciplines and extensive international business exposure. He has been involved with PostgreSQL as a contributor since 2001. He is also the author and maintainer of a PostgreSQL procedural language handler for the R language, PL/R. Joe currently manages credativ USA, which specializes in open source software with a comprehensive range of services, including consulting, architectural and technical advice, software development, training, and personalized support.


Agenda

6:30 - Food and beverages

7:00 - Intro and announcements

7:15 - Talk

8:30 - Head to Tonic for drinks
other.name: Using R In The Database: Easy Statistical Analysis in PostgreSQL with PL/R

other.description: On the first Wednesday of the month, we'll gather to socialize, network, and hear about the work people are doing with maps, GIS, geodata, and more.
other.name: Monthly Meetup

other.description:
Hack and Tell will be at WeWork Chinatown again in May! (Hooray!) Everyone is looking forward to hearing about *your* cool hack! Presentation signups are here:

http://bit.ly/presentatdc

The format is informal, engaging, and friendly: presenters have 5 minutes to show off their hack (it goes faster than you’d expect) and then the audience has 5 minutes to ask questions, make jokes, and suggest ideas and feedback. The hacks that people present are anything from how to train your dog to text you when it needs a walk to [something more serious... like blenders made out of artichokes]. Show us what you’ve got! But remember: no startup pitches, no dull work projects, no deckware!

If you’re interested in presenting, complete this short form to let us know: http://bit.ly/presentatdc

See you at the meetup! We'll start close to seven. There may be a couple beers. It's going to be fun! :) Big thanks to WeWork for hosting us! We love WeWork! We love you! We love hacks! <3
other.name: Round 20: Severe Municipal Jazz

other.description: More details coming!
other.name: Get Moving with Data - DIDC Welcomes The Department of Transportation

venue.name: Georgetown University School of Continuing Studies

other.description:
What You'll Learn

Data quality is a fundamental issue for data science that can be measured in many different ways.  Whether the data is stored in a relational database, a hierarchical file, or in key/value pairs, the reliability of your analysis depends on the quality of the data involved.  In this talk, Joe Sremack will discuss what data quality is, the categories in which data quality can be measured, and common data quality issues.  Sample data and Python code will be shown to illustrate what data quality issues are and how they can be identified.

Our Speaker

Joe Sremack is a Director in Berkeley Research Group’s Technology Services Group.  He has spent over a decade performing digital investigations for some of the largest civil and criminal cases in US History, such as the Bernie Madoff and Allen Stanford Ponzi scheme investigations.  His work involves the collection and analysis of organizations’ data, where data quality is a frequent issue

Agenda

6:30 - Food & drinks

7:00 - Intro

7:10 - Talk

8:30 - Drinks at Tonic
other.name: Measuring, Maintaining and Improving Data Quality
